fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. go to a diff that includes some comments. For instance [code|https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/CONF/repos/confluence/pull-requests/5108/diff#confluence-core/confluence/src/java/com/atlassian/confluence/upgrade/upgradetask/attachmentceo/AttachmentToContentMigrator.java].
2. Open the side by side diff view
3. Collapse the sidebar or the filetree bar
4. Scroll down

Result: Highlighted areas are un-synced after the comment.

*What it is*
We miss some scenarios when we need to refresh the segment connectors on the middle gutter between two editor on side-by-side view.
That causes the misalignments.

*The fix*
To review and add more event which we trigger the refresh.

*The main concern*
How does it affect the performance. (However, we should fix it anyway.)
fields.summary: Red and Green zones in the side-by-side view get broken when scroll after collapse the sidebar

fields.description:
The names for branch prefixes in Stash Branching should allow a limited set of variables inside the name of the configured branch prefix, including a {{STASH_USERNAME}} variable.

This would allow a large team following a convention of organizing branches first by username, followed second by the nature of the branch.
fields.summary: Branching: Custom Prefix Variables

fields.description: When hovering and getting the tooltip to add a line comment to a pull request.  If you use the keyboard shortcuts (j/k) to change which file you are viewing the tooltip stays on the screen even after moving the mouse.  This leads to multiple tooltips on the screen at one time that don't dismiss.
fields.summary: Comment tooltip sticking when using keyboard shortcuts to go to next file

fields.description:
[stackedit|https://stackedit.io/editor] renders sequence diagrams and flow charts in markdown with the following syntax:

{code}
```flow
st=>start: Start
e=>end
op=>operation: My Operation
cond=>condition: Yes or No?

st->op->cond
cond(yes)->e
cond(no)->op
```
{code}

as

!http://monosnap.com/image/spppVfQnGeGXn1yN9Vxz0CbDgrmOYT.png!

Would be great if Stash could do this too.
fields.summary: sequence and flow rendering in stash markdown

fields.description:
The count of pull requests the inbox for a user also includes PRs that the user does not have access to. This creates an inconsistent view when the user clicks on the pull request inbox and sees less pull requests than what the count shows. This can be reproduced by removing a users permissions from a repository after they've been added to a project.

*Steps to reproduce*

# Create a pull request in Repo1 and add UserA as a reviewer
## PR inbox shows 1 pull request
# Create a pull request in Repo2 and add UserA as a reviewer
## PR inbox shows 2 pull requests
# Remove UserA from the permissions in Repo2 so they no longer have access to it
# Inbox will show a badge of 2 pull requests, but clicking on the badge only shows 1
fields.summary: Pull request inbox count includes PRs that the user does not have permission to

fields.description:
According to [this Q/A|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/12779898/answers/12780762] and [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Notifications] Stash will not send email notifications when a cascade merge fails.

Here is what I am requesting. Whenever there a cascade merge fails, it immediately creates a PR (Pull Request) under the person's name (who merged the initial change). I really would like Stash to email that person him/herself so that they know there is a cascade failure (which mostly happens during merge conflicts).

If this does not happen, there is risk that the person will not know that there is a failure, and they will let that PR sit a while before they notice and do anything about it. This not only slows down the time it takes for changes to propagate, but it blocks any preceding release branches from cascading forward.
fields.summary: Email notifications when cascade merge fails

fields.description:
In the current REST API (3.7.0) it is not possible to view the annotated tag message. It is quite useful, because a lot of people save the release notes in this message. 
In our company we have a tool, which shows release info based on tags. Because the Stash REST API cannot report the tag messages, we have to check out the repo and parse the output of {{git -n}}.

Maybe you can add the message text to the *tags* method  (/rest/api/1.0/projects/\{projectKey}/repos/\{repositorySlug}/tags)
fields.summary: Show annotated tag message in REST API

fields.description:
It would be great if Stash allowed you to configure some kind of inactivity window, wherein any PRs that have had no activity (comments, approvals, pushes, etc) in that timeframe will be automatically declined, with a message explaining why.

I wouldn't expect something like this to be enabled by default, but rather something you can opt in to on a per-repo basis.
fields.summary: Auto-decline stale PRs

fields.description:
Same as https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-4631 but for Groups.

Given this scenario:
Stash <> Crowd > LDAP

If the connection to LDAP is lost, when the directory comes back online the *groups* must have the following data kept:
- global permission
- project permission
- repository permissions
- branch permissions
fields.summary: Preserve group data upon loss of connection to external user directory

fields.description:
In order to protect maintenance and release branches in Stash from being deleted via {{git push}} using refspecs, we used the [ref-change-settings plugin|https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/stash-refchange-settings-plugin]. This restricted the ability to delete branches only to administrators.

Unfortunately, with release 2.8, Stash offers _anyone_ with the {{REPO_WRITE}} permission on a repository to delete *_any_* branch in that repository from the _Branches_ tab in the Stash UI. (see STASH-3347).

This was followed by the new [REST API offered by the Branch Utilities Plugin|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/stash/2.10.0/stash-branch-utils-rest.html], which also allowed anyone with the {{REPO_WRITE}} permission on a repository to delete *_any_* branch in that repository.
 
The [ref-change-settings plugin|https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/stash-refchange-settings-plugin] does not get called here and thus cannot help us protect these branches anymore.

It would be a good idea to restrict such destructive actions (as was the intent of the [ref-change-settings plugin|https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/stash-refchange-settings-plugin]) to a smaller group of people (e.g. people with the REPO_ADMIN permission)
fields.summary: restrict ability to delete branches to REPO_ADMIN

fields.description:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/JIRA+integration
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Linking+Stash+with+JIRA

Both of these documents make no mention of needing the View Development Panel permission in JIRA in order to see the Development Panel in JIRA.  This seems like a basic requirement of the integration and should be included.
fields.summary: Add more information on required JIRA permissions to Stash/JIRA integration documents,

fields.description:
If Stash could detect/remember the base branch from which a feature branch is created, it could automatically pre-select it as the destination during pull request creation.

--- Original suggestion ---
This would be useful for when you need to merge pull requests for release branches e.g., {{fix/1.x/bugfix}} into {{release/1.x}}. When a pull request is created, the correct release branch could be selected automatically. This will be a pleasant experience and reduce errors caused by having the default branch selected by default for the destination.
fields.summary: Creating pull requests should automatically select destination branch

fields.description:
The diff viewer implements its own "sub window" which is not searchable by the browser except for the text currently displayed. The diff window does have its own find but no way to search for the same text again, or for the next or previous match. This makes it extremely difficult to navigate large diffs.

A fuller featured find with next and previous will be much appreciated.
fields.summary: Find in diff doesn't keep history and doesn't have next or previous

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of March 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

I'm excited to share that in Bitbucket Server 7.0 we shipped redesigned and optimized pull request page, including uneven scroll in side-by-side diff.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.0 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-0-release-notes-990546638.html] and Pull Requests [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/review-and-discuss-a-pull-request-808488540.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original message*

The side-by-side view of the diff viewer creates linked change "bubbles" that result in uneven scrolling of the two diffs. In cases where a lot of new code is added to a file, it becomes rather difficult to keep track of where in the file changes were made. This might be a preference, but I find the empty code blocks as used by GitHub or ReviewBoard to be easier to navigate.

Could you add an option to switch between the two and we can have the best of both.
fields.summary: Disable uneven scroll in diff viewer

fields.description: In Stash on the Pull Request page, I would like to see only pull requests with a specific destination branch.
fields.summary: Filter Pull request view on destination branch

fields.description:
When you format text with backticks, if that text is also inside a link, the text inside backticks will not be highlighted as a hyperlink. This makes it difficult to tell that text formatted with backticks is a link. This is a very common case in my experience, as it is often useful to show the name of a function and have it be a link to its source/documentation.

{code}
[example `monospaced` link]()
{code}

How GitHub formats the above markdown:
!http://i.imgur.com/RmDL50T.png!

How Stash formats the above markdown:
!http://i.imgur.com/HRcMJaN.png!

As you can tell, if there were no surrounding text, the reader would have no idea the text was a link.
fields.summary: Show hyperlinked <code> elements in blue

fields.description:
*NOTE*
In 3.7.1, we'll be shipping a workaround that makes the remember-me problem less likely to occur. This workaround will however not _completely_ eliminate all remember-me problems.
A real fix for the problem (a rewrite of the remember-me functionality) is expected to ship in 3.8.0.



A race condition has been discovered in remember-me authentication where two parallel HTTP requests provide the same remember-me cookie to Stash. 

The first request authenticates successfully and a new remember-me token is generated and returned to the browser.

The second request attempts to authenticate using the \-now stale\- token and is rejected. Furthermore, Stash detects that it is a stale token and as a safety precaution against cookie theft attacks invalidates all remember-me tokens for the user, including the new cookie that was just returned.
fields.summary: Remember-me authentication sometimes doesn't work

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you open and close a connection really fast it seems to hold onto lots of them in IoServiceListenerSupport.
In the wild this is sometimes caused by haproxy health checks.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
The problem can be reproduced running this python script:
{code}
import socket
import sys

TCP_IP = '127.0.0.1'
TCP_PORT = 7999

def makeTestConnection():
        s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
        s.connect((TCP_IP, TCP_PORT))
        s.close()

numConnections = 10000
if len(sys.argv) == 2:
        numConnections = int(sys.argv[1])

for i in range(numConnections):
        print(str(i))
        makeTestConnection()
{code}

h3. Expected Results
The session object number is small.

h3. Actual Results
If you take a heap dump afterwards you will see lots of session objects.
There seems to be a 2 minute auth timeout that gets hit and some of the sessions are removed but the majority are not removed.
Creating 10000 connections in seems to result in around 7000 of them hanging around.

Eclipse Memory Analyzer output:
{noformat}
Class Name                                      | Objects | Shallow Heap | Retained Heap
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
org.apache.sshd.server.session.ServerSession    |   6,841 |    1,860,752 |              
org.apache.sshd.common.io.nio2.Nio2Session      |   6,841 |      492,552 |              
org.apache.sshd.common.future.DefaultCloseFuture|  13,685 |      437,920 |              
org.apache.sshd.common.util.Buffer              |   6,841 |      164,184 |              
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
{noformat}

This condition could lead to an OutOfMemoryError.

This problem has been raised against Apache [SSHD-417 - Memory leak in IoServiceListenerSupport.managedSessions when clients cut connections quickly|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SSHD-417], which has now been resolved.
fields.summary: SSH holds onto some sessions.

fields.description:
Related to https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/12270327 .
It would be great to have an option to schedule regular, pre-emptive Git GC's. (e.g. run GC every day at 2:00AM or every week on Sunday at 5:00AM)

Git GC is quite resource-intensive on big repos and the response time towards users degrades while it is running.
I would like Stash to run pre-emptive GC's at times of low load, to avoid them being triggered automatically by Git after a push in the middle of the workday.
fields.summary: Create option for scheduling regular Git GC's

fields.description:
If a portion of a file is independently deleted in two branches, then sometimes the diff view is incorrect.

To reproduce, create a new repo in stash, then run the attached shell script (changing the remote URL if needed), and view the diff between master and branch:

http://localhost:7990/stash/projects/TEST/repos/diffbug/compare/diff?targetBranch=refs%2Fheads%2Fmaster&sourceBranch=refs%2Fheads%2Fbranch

Expected results: the diff view shows the first line changed from 'MASTER START' to 'BRANCH START', like 'git diff master branch' shows:

$ git diff master branch
diff --git a/test.txt b/test.txt
index 9199536..91ad9bb 100644
--- a/test.txt
+++ b/test.txt
@@ -1,3 +1,3 @@
-MASTER START
+BRANCH START
 
 END

Actual results: the diff view shows the 'MIDDLE' section having been deleted as well as the first line changing

Reversing the source/dest branches (ie http://localhost:7990/stash/projects/TEST/repos/diffbug/compare/diff?targetBranch=refs%2Fheads%2Fbranch) shows the ONLY the middle section changing WITHOUT the first line changing.

 This affects both the side-by-side diff and the unified Once a pull request is made, then the diff in the PR is correct.
fields.summary: Diff is incorrect when source branch modified before destination branch

fields.description:
We have an automated system that assigns reviewers based on the specifics of a pull request, i.e. if the pull request touches certain files, or certain packages, or contains certain items, we add certain reviewers (who hopefully have expertise with these specific files).

We'd like to be able to mark certain reviewers as "mandatory", i.e. the pull request cannot be merged unless that specific reviewer approves.

Ideally, this would also work with groups ( STASH-2870 ), i.e. at least 1 reviewer from a particular group should approve in order to allow a merge (in the group case, you would say that "1 approval from this group of people is required").
fields.summary: Allow marking a specific reviewer (or "one person among a group") to be mandatory approver before a pull request can be merged

fields.description:

fields.description:
When merging a pull request it is normally useful to delete the branch afterwards, but in some cases, such as when merging special feature or develop branches, this should _never_ be able to happen _except_ when manually deleted by an administrator.

Currently Stash remembers the user's setting for that check box which can cause issues because users end up ignoring that setting and assume the branch will be deleted. This is usually fine but can be quite dangerous, leading to interruption in workflow.

There is an issue open already [STASH-2057|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-2507] that would entirely solve this problem. It would be great if this history could be removed or configurable by an admin until then.

fields.description:
This issue happened when I attempted to change the password of an existing LDAP Authentication User Directory configured in Stash.

Typing a new password in the "Server Settings" -> "Password" field and then clicking the "Test Settings" button shows a "Connection test successful" message as expected.

However, *if the password is not re-typed in the password field a second time before clicking the "Save and Test" button, the correct password is not saved*, and connections to the LDAP server fail. There is no indication that the password needs to be re-typed a second time after clicking "Test Settings".

I noticed that the password field is populated with a placeholder mask after clicking "Save and Test", so maybe the mask is getting saved instead of the real password?

I was able to reproduce this issue when accessing Stash 3.6.1 using Firefox 35.0.1 on Mac OS X Yosemite.
fields.summary: LDAP Credentials Not Persisted After "Test Settings"

fields.description:
Under certain circumstances, the number of concurrent connections to the Crowd server will fall to the default of 2 instead of the configured 20. This can cause a bottleneck for authentication attempts to the Stash server.

*Steps to reproduce*

* Configure a User Directory to connect to the Crowd server over the default port for either HTTP or HTTPS.
** {{https://server.com/crowd}}
* Attempt to login after turning on Crowd debug logging in Stash
** {{curl -X PUT -u USER https://server.com/stash/rest/api/latest/logs/logger/com.atlassian.crowd/DEBUG}}
* The logs will show that a maximum of 2 connections are allowed for the route.
{code}@8CUIBPx573x1141x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.rest.service.RestExecutor Constructed https://server.com/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/authentication?username=jeffcrowd
2015-02-12 09:33:33,708 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-1] @8CUIBPx573x1141x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.r.s.u.ShutdownIgnoringMultiThreadedHttpConnectionManager Connection request: [route: {s}->https://server.com:443][total kept alive: 1; route allocated: 1 of 2; total allocated: 1 of 20]
2015-02-12 09:33:33,708 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-1] @8CUIBPx573x1141x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.r.s.u.ShutdownIgnoringMultiThreadedHttpConnectionManager Connection leased: [id: 4][route: {s}->https://server.com:443][total kept alive: 0; route allocated: 1 of 2; total allocated: 1 of 20]
2015-02-12 09:33:34,222 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-1] @8CUIBPx573x1141x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.rest.service.RestExecutor Cache response for POST https://server.com/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/authentication?username=jeffcrowd was CACHE_MISS
2015-02-12 09:33:34,223 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-1] @8CUIBPx573x1141x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.r.s.u.ShutdownIgnoringMultiThreadedHttpConnectionManager Connection [id: 4][route: {s}->https://server.com:443] can be kept alive indefinitely
2015-02-12 09:33:34,223 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-1] @8CUIBPx573x1141x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.r.s.u.ShutdownIgnoringMultiThreadedHttpConnectionManager Connection released: [id: 4][route: {s}->https://server.com:443][total kept alive: 1; route allocated: 1 of 2; total allocated: 1 of 20]{code}

*Expected result*

20 connections should be allowed for a route:

{code}2015-02-10 17:38:23,619 DEBUG [http-nio-7990-exec-3] @HDCY0Px1058x22359x0 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 "POST /j_stash_security_check HTTP/1.1" c.a.c.i.r.s.u.ShutdownIgnoringMultiThreadedHttpConnectionManager Connection request: [route: {}->http://localhost:8095][total kept alive: 0; route allocated: 0 of 20; total allocated: 0 of 20]{code}

*Workaround*

Use a port other than 80 or 443 to connect to the Crowd server.
fields.summary: Only 2 concurrent connections allowed to external Crowd server

fields.description:
If a reviewer opens a pull-request in browser, then comments or approves it, and meanwhile the pull-request is updated, the comment or approve is applied to the new pull-request state without reviewer noticing it.

Steps:
1. Developer creates a pull-request
2. Reviewer opens the pull-request in browser
3. developer push another commit C to the pull-request.
4. reviewer comments a change in the pull-request, which is changed in the commits C

result: the comment fails to bind to a code
expected: it should be shown in a context with note "Outdated"

the approve variation, I think it is serious:
4a. reviewer approves the pull-request

result: pull-request is approved without reviewing C
expected: reviewer must look at the updated PR to be able to approve it. PS: In this case, auto-unapproving plugin was installed, it did not help.
fields.summary: Comment/Approve vs Push race

fields.description:

- Here is some persons who performs the review. The latest one click "merge" and not marked in the review as a man who approve it.

This behavior seems strange. If you merge Review - you automatically agree with what is written in it. And you will be automatically marked as latest it.

fields.description:
I had created a project in Stash with an empty git repository.
Then I had added my public key to the project with "READ" permission (not "read/write".

Then I could clone the project in my local development environment, but I could not push my changes to the empty project, because git gives me this error:

{noformat}
fatal: remote error: Insufficient permissions
You do not have permission to push to the repository mytestprojectrepo in
project MyTestProject
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
{noformat}

This error strongly suggests that the "read" permissions are not properly set in Stash, but they are!

When I re-add the public key to my Stash project, but now with "read/write" permissions, the "problem" is gone.

Just a triviality, but still ...
fields.summary: git push permission error message contains "read", but should be "write" permission error

fields.description:
Heap dump #2 of SSP-7301 shows an atlassian-profiler {{ProfilingTimerBean}} for request {{"GET /rest/remote-link-aggregation/latest/aggregation"}} taking up 275MB of retained size.

Drilling down into the trace shows 889672 nested calls to {{PermissionService.isRepositoryAccessible}} each of which is 304 bytes. This alone is responsible for 257 Mb, so there's probably a bit more going on.

We need to 

* Exclude our high frequently called methods (e.g. anything on PermissionService) from profiling
* Investigate why remote-link-aggregating involves so many permission checks
* Check whether we can make atlassian-profiler smart enough to stop profiling once it has accumulated more than 500 or 1000 elements in the tree.
fields.summary: OutOfMemoryError triggered by atlassian-profiling

fields.description:
In our team it sometimes happens that someone wants his/her code reviewed halfway through to vent issues and concerns about the current code.
Right now the only way is to open a _temporary_ pull-request which is, after review, automatically declined by the reviewer since the branch isn't complete and ready for merge but this is, as I write, a temporary solution.

What we would want is a *Code Review Request* to accompany the Pull Request so that our developers can open a request for a review where we can comment and add tasks halfway through the development process. This would look more or less exactly like the Pull Request except there would be no way to _accidentally_ merge the branch.
fields.summary: Review request as well as pull requests

fields.description:
Stash provides an AOP pointcut (see {{crowd-spi-context.xml}}) that configures transactions on the various methods of embedded Crowd's services to ensure that they work correctly. 

Starting from Crowd 2.7, Crowd now also uses Spring's @Transactional annotations. This means that now two layers of transactions are being applied to Crowd's services and in some cases these transactional settings conflict.

One specific example is :

{noformat}
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] org.springframework.transaction.IllegalTransactionStateException: Existing transaction found for transaction marked with propagation 'never'
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.transaction.support.AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.handleExistingTransaction(AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.java:401) ~[spring-tx-4.1.1.RELEASE.jar:4.1.1.RELEASE]
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at org.springframework.transaction.support.AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.getTransaction(AbstractPlatformTransactionManager.java:349) ~[spring-tx-4.1.1.RELEASE.jar:4.1.1.RELEASE]
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at com.atlassian.owd.manager.directory.DirectoryManagerGeneric.synchroniseCache(DirectoryManagerGeneric.java:246) ~[crowd-core-2.8.1-m3.jar:na]
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdDirectoryServiceImpl.synchroniseDirectory(CrowdDirectoryServiceImpl.java:199) ~[embedded-crowd-core-2.8.1-m3.jar:na]
[INFO] [talledLocalContainer] 	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.crowd.CustomizedCrowdDirectoryService.synchroniseDirectory(CustomizedCrowdDirectoryService.java:100) ~[stash-service-impl-3.5.0.jar:na]
{noformat}
fields.summary: Embedded Crowd's transaction setting clash with Stash's transaction settings

fields.description:
The particular case I'm having a problem with:

The person who opened a PR forgot to make a particular change on one of the lines in a file. I went to comment there to leave a task/write a note...but then was faced with the message that I'm not allowed to comment unless it's within 10 lines of a change (see attachment). Now I'm left to reference the line number instead from a regular comment...

Why can't I just comment on any line in any file? There's definitely the use case of someone wanting to comment on other areas of the source where the dev hasn't necessarily made a change.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
- Go to the source tab in a repo
- Browse into any file
- Press CTRL+F [The search bar comes up at the top of the file]
- Type something that does occur in the file (do NOT press Enter afterwards)
[Nothing happens]
- Click down/up arrows on the right side of the search field
[Nothing happens]

(All this in any browser.)

While writing this, I accidentally found out that if I press enter after typing into the search field, search results actually do appear. (Took me almost a month to discover, most search fields on web pages work differently.)

Clicking the arrows next to the search field (without pressing Enter first) should definitely trigger the search.

Please also consider search-as-you-type (i.e. every character in the search field triggers the search, maybe only after N(3?) characters). As far as I can see, this would not be too resource-intensive, unless the user is browsing a really huge file.
fields.summary: Search broken in browse file pages

fields.description:
{{FlatteningCommentPropertyProvider}} does not deduplicate the comments when 'flattening' the {{CommentPropertyContext}}.

As a result, descendants of that SPI class can provide properties for the same comments multiple times which creates {{IllegalArgumentException: duplicate key}} when the properties are added to the comment.

For example:

{noformat}
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: duplicate key: likedBy
	at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkArgument(Preconditions.java:115) ~[guava-11.0.2-atlassian-02.jar:na]
	at com.google.common.collect.RegularImmutableMap.<init>(RegularImmutableMap.java:72) ~[guava-11.0.2-atlassian-02.jar:na]

fields.description:
How to reproduce:

# Create a pull request with multiple changes to a file (hunks)
# Add a line comment at the bottom of the diff
# Go to the overview and find the comment that was just added
# Click on the file name that links to the diff

Expected: The diff is opened with the file, with the part of the diff where the comment is in view.
Actual: The diff is opened with the file, but the top of the diff is in view

Because of the current behavior, the user has to find the comment manually by scrolling to it or using the browser's find functionality.

(This was derived from STASH-4190, and implementing it would make it easier to go to the full diff and expand it there.)
fields.summary: Link to diff from comment in pull request overview should go to line

fields.description:
When STASH_USER is set, {{start-stash.sh}} starts Tomcat through a call to {{runuser}} or {{su}}. However, it does so without passing the {{-l}} flag and as a result, the standard Linux login hooks that set up the environment variables are not evaluated.

This means that you cannot set {{JAVA_HOME}} in the STASH_USER's {{~/.profile}} file.

To fix:

* Add the -l flag to the command
* Add a comment to {{setenv.sh}} listing places where the STASH_HOME and JAVA_HOME variables can be defined.
* Review the public installation documentation and ensure that the same suggestions are made there.

*Workaround*
Define {{JAVA_HOME}} and/or {{STASH_HOME}} in {{/etc/environment}}. Note that these variables will then apply system-wide.
fields.summary: STASH_USER .profile is not evaluated when starting Stash through start-stash.sh

fields.description:
We realised that the Windows Service is not setting anything for the following JVM property:
{noformat}
-XX:MaxPermSize
{noformat}

That has been the culprit for a few customers trying to evaluate Stash -- it gets stuck and doesn't startup properly.

Specifically :
- Starting up Stash as a service caused Stash to get stuck
- Starting up using {{start-stash.bat}} would bring it up just fine
- After including {{-XX:MaxPermSize=512m}} to the service, it worked out well starting Stash as a service.

The error message which gets logged is:
{code}
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space
{code}

To update the MaxPermSize configuration in the service users must:

* Open a command prompt as the administrator user
* Go into the Stash installation directory and run {{bin\tomcat8w.exe //ES//AtlassianStash}}. This will open the Tomcat service configuration window.
* In the Java tab update the Jvm Options to set {{-XX:MaxPermSize=512m}}
* Apply the changes and re-start the service

Alternatively customers are encouraged to upgrade Java to version 1.8 in which PermGen errors will no longer be present. In Stash versions earlier than {{3.5.0}} the Tomcat service configuration tool will need to be used to update the path to the newly installed JVM. Stash versions {{3.5.0}} and higher set this configuration in an environment variable.
fields.summary: Windows service not defining -XX:MaxPermSize is causing Stash to get stuck on startup

fields.description:
The message "User not permitted" is being displayed when accessing Stash pull requests which has merge conflict whereby the source branch is from a forked repository and its target a branch in the main repository. This message is misleading and should either be changed or removed.

In addition, after receiving the "User not permitted" message for the pull requests with merge conflict:

1. The warning message box with text "This pull request can't be merged. You will need to resolve conflicts to be able to merge. More information."
2. The warning icon located on the left of the Merge button
    are missing for the following scenario:
2a) As the reviewer, in the pull request's "Overview" tab
2b) As the creator of a pull request if the pull request is created in a Stash version prior to 3.6.0

Can you please investigate the "User not permitted" unexpected message and the missing merge warning indicators for pull requests with merge conflicts whereby the source branch is from a forked repository to a target branch in the main repository.

From further testing, noted that:
- "User not permitted" message appears if the reviewer does not have permission to access the forked repository
- "User not permitted" message does not appear if the reviewer has write permission to the forked repository
Perhaps there is a change in Stash v3.6.0 that introduced this behavior since we did not see this message with earlier versions of Stash.

fields.description:
Jira (nice auto revert ability) & Confluence have the ability to edit the look & feel for all users, but stash does not.

You may prefer the full year in the format dd MMM yyyy instead of dd MMM yy (so users aren't confused which is the year).

Or you may prefer ultra international sort capable yyyy-MM-dd k:mm

Server wide is fine, not requesting we go all the way to per-user setting just yet.

Related tickets:
STASH-3178 added the ability to edit theme/color via a look & feel plugin - apologies if you'd prefer it to file into https://bitbucket.org/atlassianlabs/stash-look-and-feel-plugin/issues
STASH-4828 already internationalized the dates based on server language setting
STASH-4477 is asking for ability to disable relative dates
fields.summary: look and feel settings - date and time formats

fields.description:
After one of the nodes was restarted in a Data Center installation, the SSH server on that node failed to start correctly with a {{NullPointerException}}. The same {{NullPointerException}} is triggered wherever the SSH configuration is accessed, which lead to a crippled node.

Investigation uncovered the cause: the {{OsgiClassLoaderRegistry}} got out of sync between the nodes. As a result, one node serialized the {{SshConfiguration}} using a bundle ID that the other node did not recognize. As a result, the other node failed to deserialize the object and returned null.

An INFO log message was logged, but this was not logged in Stash's logs because the logging level for that particular class is set to WARN by default.

Changes to be made:

* Change the {{OsgiClassLoaderRegistry}} to ensure it can never get out of sync between the nodes.
* Harden the SSH configuration code to handle cache load failures more gracefully.
* Change the log message to WARN
* Change the default log level for com.atlassian.hazelcast to INFO in Stash

*Workaround*

Restarting all nodes in the Data Center instance brings the {{OsgiClassLoaderRegistry}} on all nodes back in sync.
fields.summary: Data Center node restart triggers NullPointerException when accessing SshConfiguration

fields.description:
When permissions are granted or revoked to a group, the permission cache is updated. Usually the group names are lowercased, but for these dynamic updates, the lowercasing isn't happening. 

For example, the permissions cache is updated for group 'Administrators', but the permission checks are done for group 'administrators'. As a result, the permission checks do not 'see' the updated permissions.
fields.summary: When permissions are granted or revoked to groups with upper case letter in them, the permissions are not effective until a restart

fields.description:
If there are users in the {{cwd_user}} table that have no matching user in the {{sta_normal_user}} table, the /admin/users page errors out.

Stash was upgraded from 2.9.4 to 3.5.0

*Workaround*

Determine which users are missing in the {{sta_normal_user}} table

{code:sql}
select id, user_name, lower_user_name from cwd_user where lower_user_name not in (select name from sta_normal_user);
{code}

* Under Administration > User Directories, disable all remote directories
* For each of the missing users, go to /admin/users and create a user with the same username. This will create the user in the built-in user directory and will also create the user in the {{sta_normal_user}} table. Don't worry about the password or sending an email to the user, because next we'll...
* Delete the user that was just created. This will remove the user from the built-in user directory, but the user in {{sta_normal_user}} will be retained.
* Re-enable the user directories that were disabled in step 1
fields.summary: Users list in administration fails with 500 status after upgrade to Stash 3.5

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi,

Good news! In Bitbucket Data Center 7.2, we added BranchCreatedEvent and BranchDeletedEvent to the Audit log. These events will be audited if the coverage level of _End-user activity_ is set to _Advanced_. For more information, please read Audit log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/audit-log-events-in-bitbucket-776640423.html].

Alternatively, in Bitbucket Server 7.1 we shipped Push log feature that can help you find the author and creation date of a branch. For more information, please read Bitbucket Server 7.1 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-1-release-notes-998641213.html] and Push log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/push-logs-998882984.html].

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original message*

As per the topic [https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/324546/a-way-to-determine-who-created-a-branch-in-stash] there is a way to identify addition and deletion of branches done outside Stash (e.g. via Git client), but this is not currently logged when done via Stash UI.

fields.description:
Not a normal use case, but still comes up occasionally.

Person A opens a PR, multiple comments are made and then that person gets reassigned to another task.

Person B is assigned to finish the task, essentially taking over the PR.  Person A now really needs to become a reviewer on the PR instead of the owner.  We don't want to decline the PR because there are comments made that should stay with the branch, so we're left with a strange case where the PR owner becomes a reviewer, without an Approve button.

It would be good to have the ability to transfer ownership of the PR to person B.
fields.summary: Provide ability to transfer ownership of a PR

fields.description:
Currently, we are able to modify the default branch model prefix for an existing repository.

However, there is no way to modify the default branch model prefix in Stash so that all new repository created will have the modified default branch model prefix.

It would be better if Stash admin can perform this changes so that all repo created will have the same default branch model prefix
fields.summary: Default branch model prefix for new repository

fields.description:
When I'm looking at a pull request that changes a number of files, especially when those individual changes are small, it's helpful to see the complete diff on a single page rather than clicking through to see the change file-by-file.

An example would be a Java change to repackage a class; most files will see a single-line change to their imports, and being able to scroll through all those changes is quicker than examining each file in turn. More generally, a single page makes it easier to see how the change is distributed across multiple files.

The current interface in Bitbucket is what I'm used to here, and that's worked well for me. There are definitely cases where the file-by-file model is better, but it's not universal.
fields.summary: Show the complete diff on one page during a pull request

fields.description: If the {{.gitmodules}} file in a repository contains mixed end-of-line characters (e.g. some lines \r\n and some lines \n), Stash does not detect the line endings properly and does not recognize separate lines as separate config settings.
fields.summary: "Missing configuration url for module section" error because of mixed EOL mode in .gitmodules

fields.description:
As a Bitbucket server instance administrator in my organisation, I often have to field questions from users who want to gain access to a project but don't know who is the project admin.

This is because there is nothing in the user interface which lets them know who a given project (or repo) is administrated by.

This means that we have not successfully completely delegated the administration of the project/repo, since we still have an initial query bottleneck with the instance admins, who can see the /projects/PROJECTKEY/permissions pages and can then tell the user who they should ask.

Can you please consider adding some kind of visibility of the list of admins for project/repos which the user has basic access to, such that they can direct project/repo permission requests successfully themselves?
fields.summary: Empower users to find (project) admins through web interface

fields.description:
As an engineer, I want to be able to nominate sections of code as 'Best Practice Examples' during pull request review so that I can promote best practices and reward engineers who do great work

How it might work
- It should allow nomination of code directly from the Pull Request Diff screen
- It should probably allow the entry of tags with the nomination (e.g. 'DAO','Error Handling') 
- It should be possible to find these examples in the repository by keyword to support the use case where a user is seeking best practice for a particular situation (e.g. "My DAO is throwing errors" -> Search best practice -> 'DAO' + 'Error Handling'
- some sort of simple workflow is likely needed (Nominated -> Agreed) 
- It would be cool if you could configure stash to email the team if a new piece of code has been agreed as best practice

What problems would it solve
Junior developers, when faced with a problem, tend to look to the existing code for solutions.."Somebody must have solved this before"...  This is a reasonable approach, if they can find the right code to emulate.  This enhancement would allow engineers to clearly define what is considered the best code to follow.  

'Writing up' best practice approaches is tedious and is often overlooked in favour of building more awesome software.  This approach is fast (you are already looking at the code .. just nominate it) and fits easily into a normal process flow.

For Senior developers, doing the right thing, following best practice and not taking shortcuts is often a thankless path to take.  By providing recognition of great results, nominated and agreed by peers is a great way to light up this path and encourage good behavior.
fields.summary: Nomination of Best Practice Examples

fields.description:
we wonder if diff changes can be viewed directly in the email instead of giving the link to stash and viewing there. This would help for quick review for all the changes instead switching back and forth between Email and the stash application.
Expecting a kind help or solution on this.
fields.summary: Notifier for Diff changes which can be view directly in the Email instead of link for each commit
Virtual-repo per project that includes all repos as submodules

fields.description:
If I create a hotfix branch in stash, I want my master branch to be selected automatically as a default branch.

When i do a normal feature or bug, I want my develop branch to be selected automatically as a default branch.

This lessens the risk of accidently branching from the wrong base branch in a git flow workflow.
fields.summary: As a User, I would love to be able to configure the base branch that is picked for branching, based on issue type.

fields.description:
If there is a space in the path to where the restore client is located, it will fail to find the JDBC folder and drivers causing the restore to fail.

{code}2015-01-26 17:11:47,072 WARN The jdbc directory does not exist. Jars will not be added to the classpath
2015-01-26 17:11:47,150 INFO Initializing
2015-01-26 17:11:49,666 INFO Unpacking stash-20150123-153732-214.tar to D:\Atlassian\ApplicationData\Stash
2015-01-26 17:11:50,479 ERROR stash-20150123-153732-214.tar could not be restored. Reason: The configured JDBC driver, com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver, is not available on the classpath. Ensure the jar for the driver is
present in the "jdbc" directory beneath D:\Backup Client\stash-backup-client-1.6.0\. and try again.
com.atlassian.stash.internal.backup.client.RestoreException: The configured JDBC
driver, com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver, is not available on the classpath. Ensure the jar for the driver is present in the "jdbc" directory beneath D:\Backup Client\stash-backup-client-1.6.0\. and try again.
at com.atlassian.stash.internal.backup.client.DefaultRestoreClient.createDataSource(DefaultRestoreClient.groovy:165) ~[stash-restore-client.jar:1.6.0]
at com.atlassian.stash.internal.backup.client.DefaultRestoreClient.withDataSource(DefaultRestoreClient.groovy:264) ~[stash-restore-client.jar:1.6.0]
... 7 more frames available in the log file{code}

The issue above is that the client is located in the {{Backup Client}} folder.

*Workaround*

Move the client to a directory path that does not contain any spaces.

ie. {{D:/Backup_Client/stash-backup-client-1.6.0/}}
fields.summary: Restore client fails to find JDBC driver folder when there is a space in the path

Was this feature allowing this incorrectly before, or has something broken in the current rev?

fields.description:
Suggestion is to include the username in the URL suggested by Stash in the "Issues Merging the Pull Request" popup (presented when there is a conflict in a Pull Request).

Currently the URL shown is as follows:
!pr1.png|thumbnail!

Without the username in the URL the fetch command may fail if a user has to be specified:
* In Windows with Git 2+ it was observed the command prompts user to insert a username.
* In OSX with Git 1.9.3 (Apple Git-50) the command just fails.

This suggestion is made based on the same way the URLs are offered when creating an empty repository in Stash, in which URLs for cloning the repository are provided containing the username.
Please also notice the URLs are fully shown as per the screenshot when a Pull Request is created between different repositories (e.g. from a forked repo to the original).
fields.summary: Include username in URL suggested by Stash

fields.description:
Currently the @ mention feature searches all users in the Stash directory even if they are not a licensed Stash user. Since it's not possible for non-licensed users to login to Stash, they should not be included in the list of results.

The current behavior can cause all users to be loaded into memory during a search. If enough users are synced to Stash, this can cause OOME. For example, if 100,000 users are synced to Stash, but only 1,000 are licensed users, all 100,000 users are loaded into memory.

*Workaround*

# Limit the LDAP user filter to only sync users that should have access to Stash or a smaller subset of the larger user base.
fields.summary: Limit @ mention list to only licensed users
